content.description:
Worth a run if in the area; if it weren’t for a 10-foot-long patch of vegetation in the dihedral, this would be three stars.

War Paint

is the dihedral/crack system just left of

The Liberator

.  Face climb into the dihedral and follow the crack to the chains shared with

The Liberator

.  According to the Ruckmans (1998): “Some slippery stems provide entertainment.”
content.protection: A set of cams from ¾ to 2 inches; consider taking a few extra finger-size and thin-hands-size.

content.description:
If

The Liberator

were on Challenge Buttress, it would be the most climbed 10a in BCC.  It pieces together a cool set of features, all on superb rock.   Climb past six bolts to chains.  The Ruckmans’ 1998 guide says of the route, “devious.”  Probably best for the experienced 5.10 leader; the bolts are 27 years old and have SMC hangers.
content.protection: Six draws plus two for the chains.
content.location: This is on the west face of Liberator Ridge, which is the ridge just east of Lower Education Ridge (see beta photo).  As you thrash up the left side of Liberator Ridge, you’ll get to a section of really good rock.  Just ahead is a sole cedar tree.  Drop your packs here and spot the first bolt maybe 10 feet off the ground.

content.description:
The most obvious feature of this route is the attractive left-leaning, left-facing dihedral on the upper part of the crag, right of

The Liberator

.  The dihedral is accessed by starting up a wide-ish crack until possible to diagonal left then slightly back right to the dihedral's base. Savor the dihedral then scamper to

The Liberator/War Paint

chains.
content.location:
The wide-ish crack marking the start of the route is just downhill from the start of the

The Liberator

bolt line.
